content:
=== Game Rules ===
This is vgdl rule file:
BasicGame square_size=32
    SpriteSet
        background > Immovable img=oryx/space1 hidden=True
        base    > Immovable    color=WHITE img=oryx/planet
        avatar  > FlakAvatar   stype=sam img=oryx/spaceship1
        missile > Missile
            sam  > orientation=UP    color=BLUE singleton=True img=oryx/bullet1
            bomb > orientation=DOWN  color=RED  speed=0.5 img=oryx/bullet2
        alien   > Bomber       stype=bomb   prob=0.01  cooldown=3 speed=0.8
            alienGreen > img=oryx/alien3
            alienBlue > img=oryx/alien1
        portal  > invisible=True hidden=True
        	portalSlow  > SpawnPoint   stype=alienBlue  cooldown=16   total=20 img=portal
        	portalFast  > SpawnPoint   stype=alienGreen  cooldown=12   total=20 img=portal

    LevelMapping
        . > background
        0 > background base
        1 > background portalSlow
        2 > background portalFast
        A > background avatar

    TerminationSet
        SpriteCounter      stype=avatar               limit=0 win=False
        MultiSpriteCounter stype1=portal stype2=alien limit=0 win=True

    InteractionSet
        avatar  EOS  > stepBack
        alien   EOS  > turnAround
        missile EOS  > killSprite

        base bomb > killBoth
        base sam > killBoth scoreChange=1

        base   alien > killSprite
        avatar alien > killSprite scoreChange=-1
        avatar bomb  > killSprite scoreChange=-1
        alien  sam   > killSprite scoreChange=2

This is vgdl rule in natural language:
This game is essentially a retro-style space shooter set in outer space. You control a spaceship (the "avatar") that can fire bullets ("sam") upward against waves of attacking enemies while protecting a central base (represented as a planet).

Genre and Setting:
• It’s a classic arcade shooter with a space theme. The background is a static image of space, and elements like the planet ("base") and the spaceship (avatar) set the stage for a battle in space.
• The level layout uses a grid of symbols (like “0” and “A”) that indicate where obstacles or decorations are placed, with your avatar starting near the bottom of the screen.

Game Mechanics:
• Movement: The spaceship moves around the screen but is kept within boundaries (if it touches the edge, it “steps back”). Enemies like aliens bounce off the edges by turning around.
• Shooting: Your spaceship fires “sam” (blue bullets that travel upward) that can hit enemy sprites and even interact with your base.
• Enemies: There are two types of alien enemies spawned from “portals” (invisible spawn points). One type, represented as alienBlue, spawns slowly while the other, alienGreen, spawns faster. These aliens are bombers that drop bombs (red projectiles moving downward) at a set probability and rate.
• Bombs and Missiles: Bombs fall from aliens; if a bomb hits the base, both the bomb and the base are destroyed. Missiles (another type of projectile) disappear when they leave the screen.
  
Interactions and Scoring:
• Positive actions include hitting aliens with your bullets. When a bullet (sam) from your avatar strikes an alien, the alien is destroyed and you gain points (+2 score).
• Hitting the base with your own bullet (sam) also destroys both (base and bullet) but gives you a smaller score bonus (+1); this could be part of a more nuanced scoring system or a risk/reward mechanic.
• Colliding with an enemy (either an alien or a bomb) with your spaceship is penalized (–1 score) and causes the offending sprite to be destroyed.
• Interestingly, if an alien touches the base, the alien is removed, which might be a protective mechanism for the base.
  
Objectives and Win/Loss Conditions:
• The overall objective is to clear the screen of enemy aliens and their spawn points (portals) so that no enemies remain.
• You win when the combined counter for portal and alien sprites reaches 0 (i.e., all enemy spawns have been neutralized).
• You lose if you lose your avatar (the spaceship), meaning if you are hit or collide with enemies, leading your sprite count to drop to 0.

Overall Strategy:
• Play defensively while remaining aggressive with your shooting: Focus on hitting the aliens with your upward bullets to accumulate points and clear threats.
• Avoid collisions with enemy aliens and bombs, as these not only remove you from play (leading to a loss) but also incur a score penalty.
• Keep an eye on your base: Although the base is immovable, it’s a critical part of the game. The base’s interactions suggest it plays a crucial role in the enemy dynamics, so consider prioritizing threats that might jeopardize it.
• Manage spawn rates: Portals spawn aliens at set intervals. Watch for these portals (even if they are invisible) by tracking the areas where enemies appear and focus your fire to eliminate them quickly.
• Use the boundaries to your advantage: Since your spaceship “steps back” from the screen edge, maintain positioning that maximizes your firing range while keeping you safe from enemies emerging from all directions.

In short, your primary goal is to use precise shooting and careful movement to take down incoming waves of aliens and bombs, protect the base, and eventually clear the screen completely of enemy forces, all while preserving your spaceship for as long as possible.

You are an intelligent player playing a video game, and you have a friend provide you strategy. Interpret the state, rule, strategy and act accordingly. Notice that your avatar position is one of the most important information, if the position doesn't change from the last state, you need to analyze the state and make a different action from the last time.

=== Available Actions ===
0: ACTION_NIL
1: ACTION_USE
2: ACTION_LEFT
3: ACTION_RIGHT

=== High Level Plan === 


Evaluation: BAD 
\Feedback: Action 3 did not advance the avatar’s position past the wall barriers, leaving it stuck in a blocked area. This failure to progress toward the objective, along with potential exposure to nearby threats, resulted in a reward of 0.0 from the environment.

=== Important Mechanics Notice ===
 In some games, directional actions (LEFT, RIGHT, UP, DOWN) may first cause the avatar to rotate toward the intended direction without immediately moving. If the avatar's position does not change after a directional action, it may indicate a rotation has occurred. To proceed, you must apply the directional action again after rotation. Always verify whether the avatar actually moved after each action. Please understand the rule and the interaction set first, then locate the item, finally choose a meaningful action towards the win and respond in the format: ``` Action:<action number> ```. Include one sentence of feedback on the action and your expectation to see if it aligns with the strategy. Notice, Action 0 will not reasult in any change in this game environment, and you may need to understand the level layout first to play the game. 

=== Sprite Mapping ===
avatar -> 'a'
background -> '.'
background base -> '0'
background portalSlow -> '1'
background portalFast -> '2'
alienBlue -> '@'
base -> '#'
sam -> '$'
alienBlue bomb -> '%'
bomb -> '&'

=== Current State ===

===Long-term Plan===
``` 
**avatar strategy: Prioritize creating safe passage by neutralizing alienBlue threats near wall barriers so that the avatar can eventually bypass these obstructions** with **Alert**
**sam strategy: Batch-process all alienBlue and alienBlue bomb units impeding progress; focus fire in blocked zones to clear enemy interference enabling pathway opening** with **Alert**
**base strategy: Utilize background base cues to identify less obstructed corridors; dynamically shift focus to bomb and alien removal in crowded zones to facilitate a continuous route for advancement** with **Alert**
```

Action:1

I’m now firing a bullet (using ACTION_USE) to try to neutralize the alien directly above, which should clear a safe path and align with our strategy of removing blocked threats.
